newsitem.title: FRANCE: France's Juppe to crack down on illegal aliens.
newsitem.headline: France's Juppe to crack down on illegal aliens.

text.p: French Prime Minister Alain Juppe, fresh from an acrimonious war of words with the far-right National Front, said on Tuesday he would next month put forward a bill cracking down on illegal immigration.

The conservative premier told a congress of parliamentarians of the UDF, junior partner in the ruling coalition, that the draft law would focus on clandestine workers, "to dry up the source of clandestine immigration".
The bill would widen the definition of clandestine work, give authorities more powers and strengthen legal sanctions.
Juppe also said that next spring at the latest the government would put forward separate measures tightening already strict rules on French nationality.
"Checks at borders and sending foreign nationals who have illegal status back to their country of origin is more than ever a priority," he said.
The new measures will aim to simplify complex procedures for the expulsion of illegal immigrants and overhaul provisions for detention of suspects.

"The law will take account of very special individual situations which this summer led to residence permits being granted on an exceptional basis," Juppe said in reference to a row over a long hunger-strike by illegal immigrants holed up in a Paris church until they were forced out by police.

While taking a tough line on illegal immigration, the government has also moved to appear sympathetic to immigrants in France accused by the far right of taking jobs from so-called native French people.
Juppe last week dubbed Jean-Marie Le Pen, leader of the anti-immigrant National Front, "deeply, almost viscerally racist, antisemitic and xenophobic".

Justice Minister Jacques Toubon is preparing draft legislation for parliament after concluding that existing laws were too weak to prosecute Le Pen for stating this month that racial inequality was "obvious" and "a fact".
